reviewText:
Tales Across Time follows, unsurprisingly given the title, the stories of three characters across different timelines: you'll eventually discover that these stories are somewhat all connected.
The game provides a very enjoyable narrative spanning across different eras and interesting, if cliched, protagonists for each story: the actual gameplay is very simple but works well enough to never get dull.

PROS:

-a good art style makes the simple graphics pleasant

-truly nice and varied soundtrack

-the plots for each timeline are a bit cliched but done well, the overarching narrative is very interesting and unfolds at a good pace

-while you don't spend hours with them each protagonist is given a decent amount of depth through their dialogue

-the game isn't afraid of being dark and/ or violent when needed

-simple yet enjoyable combat system

-going through different timelines is a compelling experience especially when you see references to the previous ones

NEUTRAL:

-could have used an instant text" option

-most enemy encounters (bosses included) provide little to no challenge

-adequate length at 3
date:
5/4 hours

CONS:

-last boss fight feels slightly drawn-out and is a bit of a chore as mechanics go (it also bugged out on me the first time)

-some relationships might feel a bit forced as they seem to bloom in a very short span of time

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=669812861

I was pretty surprised by this game
recommended: the whole "short-story across different areas" concept is what made me buy it but I wasn't expecting such an enjoable time. The actual stories aren't very original but they're still narrated with enough competence to make them enjoyable: the overarching plot is what I found to be most engaging as it affects the protagonists' lives quite deeply and it made me want to go forward to see how things'd end. Said characters also follow the tropes of the genre quite closely but they're at least given some well written dialogues that gives them some depth and makes you care for what might happen to them.\n\nAs gameplay goes things are quite simple for the most part
hoursPlayed: you have an AP system that governs skill usage and three different attack options differing in strength. AP recharge rate. Some eras will switch things up a bit but fights are never too complex or challenging: thankfully there's no random encounters and the number of fights seemed good enough to not make things dull.\n\nThe only thing that made me frown a bit was the last boss of the game: the fight itself isn't hard as the mechanics are quite easy but it feels a bit of a chore due to its length and the fact you're simply asked to balance AP usage
voteText: healing and skills. It also bugged out the first time I've attempted it
helpfulPercent:
forcing me to close the game using the taskbar and go through all the previous cutscenes.

For a 3$ game Tales Across Time is truly nicely done and smartly puts its timelines idea to good use providing an enjoyable and quite engaging narrative. Pair this with serviceable combat and a good attention to both its graphics and sound and I'm going to say this one is quite the hidden gem.

"

reviewText:
Critical Games is an Australian independent game development company that was founded in 2011. The founder of the company, Joshua Hallaran, created the first release title Path of Thanatos, in its entirety. Tales Across Time is the studio’s second title on Steam following the well reviewed 8-Bit Adventures: The Forgotten Journey Remastered Edition. It is a story-driven RPG that has been developed in the RPGMaker engine.

The story focuses on three different characters across different timelines. Although at first they do not appear to be connected it becomes obvious the more that you play throughout the story that they are intertwined. The narrative is among the best that I have experienced in an RPGMaker experience and rivals the best Aldorlea Games titles that we have featured thus far this year. Even though they are somewhat cliched and the plot points are a little predictable I did enjoy the story that was being told within the game. One of the game’s strongest points is the depth of the characters. This is something that I have often believed is overlooked in these games but it is something that the developers have paid particular attention and care to. Given their significance I am pleased that the developers delivered. Though there is room for improvement with the formulation of relationships and dialogue.

I was also pleased with the art work. This is another area that developers often overlook with the engine believing that there isn’t much that can be done with it. The art work is pleasant to look at, at times giving it as unique an appearance as you can find with the engine and the utilization of the color palette constantly keeps in line with the story being told.

The combat system is very thorough and I liked the fact that you could retry any battle if you failed without having to visit a previous checkpoint. This is something that I would like to encourage more developers to implement into their games. There is nothing worse than dying in a seemingly random encounter and then having to backtrack several minutes or even longer into already defeated content. The soundtrack was well chosen and again is keeping with the atmosphere of the story. However, my biggest disappointment also effects the combat system. The game has a lack of a leveling system. This means that regardless of how good the combat system is – and could have been – it feels as though it is there for the sake of being there rather than a firm focus and feature of the game.

At a price tag of $2.99 you’re getting very fair value for money. It’s a good game especially for an RPGMaker game (not my favorites) but this one is good. When Ainslie returns I’ll see what she has to say of the game as she enjoys them much more than I.

reviewText:
Positives+Colorful, well-crafted sprite art backgrounds, characters, and monsters
+Evocative music (reminded me of some of the best of the SNES/PS1 era RPGs)
+Low price (US$2.99 as of 04/20/2016)
+Characters each have their own personalities and convey this very well through their dialog
+Should you fall in combat you are given the option to retry without having to reload from your save
+Some very cinematic presentation techniques used on occasion

Negatives-Very low, fixed resolution (I realize the reason for this is the game engine's limitations but it was definitely a negative to have to choose between a small 1:1 window or a stretched out full screen)
-Some pretty cheesy dialog at times
-A few 'deus ex machina' moments defeat some of the built up tension in the story
-Characters seem to form incredible bonds of love, mentorship, trust, etc. within 5 minutes of meeting each other
-Monster sprites, while mostly well-made, are not always thematically consistent with their surroundings or each other
-No character levelling or skill development, so combat mostly felt like an impediment

SummaryTales Across Time is a short, sweet Adventure/RPG. It features very nice sprite art and music, and an intriguing fantasy story involving characters in multiple eras facing their own personal challenges as well as a shared supernatural foe. Combat is basic and serves mostly as a narrative device linking story segments, rather than a gameplay hook.

This is a story delivered by means of a game engine, with some pretty, if low res, visuals and nice music.

I enjoyed it.

reviewText: It's not really an RPG - there's no leveling up, no character building, no extensive fantasy story...it's just a short visual novel in the disguise of an 8-bit RPG (and I dislike visual novels). If you enjoy those types of interactive stories, then you may like this, but since it's not really a JRPG, it just comes off as boring.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the concept, and especially appreciated the focus on narrative. My only gripe with this game, and I'd hardly call it that, is that you only experience three different time periods. However, given the price of this game and overall experience, you more than get your money's worth.\n\nHighly recommend!

reviewText:
This game is great!
It's got all the great RPG stuff, without the grinding, and levelling up.
It's a story based adventure, and an achivement game.

The most you get out of it, is locating and unlocking all the achievements ~
I'd recommend it if you like stories, and achievements, over grinding, and strategising.

reviewText: Holy moly! I got finished with it and MAN! Do I recommend you get this game? Yes, yes I do.\nThe battles are not hard to figure out, and the mechanics make it fun. The story is well done and I enjoyed it very much. You'll love the characters too.\nThis is an everybody" game where everyone will enjoy it!"

reviewText:
It was a $3 game.

That's not to say it's a bad game, but you certainly get what you pay for (I'm sure this can be beaten in one sitting if you have 3 - 5 hours to kill, but I took breaks). Again, not a bad thing.

The fights were unique, which is good and bad. They were more of an annoyance, but I DID enjoy the resource management in them.

Bosses had a limited range of attacks, so it was kind of annoying to see the same attacks so much, but that's not a big deal.

Cared very little about the story to be honest. Can't say more; spoilers.

Overall, I'm not mad I got it; it was worth the money. If you have $3 and a free 3 - 5 hours to bang out a small game, do check this one out.
